bibl.title: Letter from W.A. Herron & Sons to Jesse W. Lazear, December 8, 1899

div1.p: Herron offers Lazear advice on the sale of a lot adjacent to Lazear's Denniston Avenue property.

div1.head: Letter from W.A. Herron & Sons to Jesse W. Lazear, December 8, 1899
div1.opener:
10,000-9-99.
W. A. HERRON & SONS,
REAL ESTATE AGENTS,
406 WOOD STREET,
PITTSBURG, PA
MONEY TO LOAN ON MORTGAGES.
SPECIAL ATTENTION GIVEN TO
MANAGING PROPERTY, RENTING, COLLECTING
RENTS, PAYING TAXES, ETC.
ALSO AGENTS FOR
“THE SCHENLEY ESTATE”
Dec.8-99.
Dr. Jesse W. Lazear,
835 Park Ave., Baltimore, Md.
Dear Sir,-
div1.p:
We understand your desire to sell the Denniston
Avenue property either as a whole or in parts, and therefore it would
probably be well to reserve the right to sell the corner lot in fixing
or arranging a lease from April. At the present time the whole premises
are included in the lease, and probably the house would not rent at the
present rate if both lots were not included. In case you sold off the
corner lot and there should be a building put on it, it would make your
house very dark, for that which perhaps more than anything else adds to
the desirability of your house is the fact that it has an open lot at
the side, and the tenant therefore has the use of the side lot, as well
as the benefit of light and air therefrom. But of course in selling the
side lot it would have to be in a way not to greatly damage or interfere
with your house. Your house in built back from the street line several
feet, and if you should sell the corner lot and the owner thereof should
build out on the street line, it would very greatly injure your house,
and therefore when the corner lot is improved, the building thereon
should not extend beyond the front line of your house. Then again, if
the corner lot is sold, it would probably be wise to reserve a 4 foot
alley. The property consists of 2 lots, 24 feet each, and your house
covers one full lot, and therefore if you would sell the other full lot,
there would be no space between your house and the other property, hence
we believe if you sold the corner lot, it would be better to sell about
20 feet, and that would then give an entrance way from the front, as as well
well as as arrange for light and air along the side of your present house.

It might, however, be better not to sell the corner lot until you
had sold the house, for it may be hard to sell the corner lot and have it
improved in a way that will not damage or injure not only the salability
but the renting of your house, and the lot will at any time sell much
more readily at all events than the house and lot, hence we would suggest
that it would be better to try and push the sale of the house with a lot
say 27 or 28 feet front, and not sell the corner lot until after the
house is sold. Up to the present time there has not been great demand
for houses of that class in the last few years, for newer and more modern
houses in newer and more modern districts have drawn the attention of
house buyers, and the older houses are hard to sell unless the price is
made an inducement.

Please pardon us for these suggestions, as we lay them before you
only as a matter of information and so that you may direct us how we
are to follow this matter up for your best interests, it being our desire
to accomplish that as well as do what is your pleasure in the case.
